result.hateful_meaning: A British person, derived from the Black and Tans, the nickname for an auxiliary British Army unit deployed to Ireland in the 1920s and which gained a reputation for brutality.
A black child.
A person of East Asian descent in reference to the appearance of the eyes, similar to 'slant'.
In Northern Ireland, a spide is a young working class male. A female is known as a millie.
A black person.
Used by poor rural people to denote those of lower status than themselves, particularly those who commit incest (jumping the family tree).
In the UK, a criminal dealing in counterfeit and/or stolen goods
A black person, originating from the 1940s.

[1] A person of German, Dutch, or Scandinavian, esp. Swedish, origin. [2] A Caucasian person, especially a German. Refers to either the stereotyped shape of their heads, or to the shape of the Stalhelm M1916 steel helmet, or to its owner's stubbornness (like a block of wood).

A female Native American. Derived from lower East Coast Algonquian (Massachuset: ussqua), which originally meant 'young woman', but which took on strong negative connotations in the late 20th century.

A person of Hispanic descent. First recorded use in 1915. Theories include from 'no spik English' (and spiggoty from the Chicano no speak-o t'e English), but common belief is that it is an abbreviation of 'Hispanic'.

A person of Hispanic descent. First recorded use in 1915. Theories include from 'no spik English' (and spiggoty from the Chicano no speak-o t'e English), but common belief is that it is an abbreviation of 'Hispanic'.
